item.title: bucket

item.title: deriving the vorticity equation from navier-stokes in 2d
item.description: Start with the incompressible Navier-Stokes equation Â£Â£ \begin{equation} ğâ‚tâ‚â†—v + (â†—vâ¦âˆ‡)â†—v = Î½âˆ‡â½2â¾â†—v - Ã·1ÏÂ·âˆ‡p ğ“®ğ“º{611} \end{equation} Â£Â£ where Ëâ†—v = â†—v(â†—r,t)Ë is the flow velocity (vector field) Ëp = p(â†—r,t)Ë is the pressure (scalar field) ËÏË is the density ËÎ½Ë is the kinematic viscosity, ËÎ½ = Î¼/ÏË Some context: the NSE is an equation for the time evolution of the fluid’s velocity field. The specific form of the equation derives from momentum conservation (and whatever assumptions you deign to make about the fluid, e.

item.title: the vorticity equation in a rotating frame
item.description: The NSE: Â£Â£ \begin{equation} ÆŠâ‚tâ‚â†—v = Î½âˆ‡â½2â¾â†—v - Ã·1Ïâˆ‡p ğ“®ğ“º{621} \end{equation} Â£Â£ where ËÆŠâ‚tâ‚Ë is the advective derivative, ËÆŠâ‚tâ‚ = ğâ‚tâ‚ + (â†—vâ¦âˆ‡)Ë. Suppose we’re now in a rotating reference frame RF that’s rotating at angular velocity Ëâ†—Î©Ë w.r.t. the inertial frame IF. Since all the vector quantities are now fixed in the rotating frame, you have to transform them to a form that’s valid in the inertial frame. Let Ëâ†—rË be the position vector, Ëâ†—r = âˆ‘â‚iâ‚râ‚iâ‚â†‘eâ‚iâ‚Ë.
